msItem.filiation: Guglielmetti and Keats-Rohan indicate that the manuscript is an apograph of the Malmesbury manuscript, now Oxford, Bodleian Library, Barlow 6. (Webb, 1:xvi, indicates that the two were closely related, but stopped short of calling Barlow 48 a direct copy, probably because he had not been able to account for the correcting activities of Walter de Meldia described by Gullick.)

collation.signatures: Gatherings numbered, I–XVIII, in ink on the first and sometimes the last page of each gathering, at the foot of the page.
collation.catchwords: Catchwords at the end of most gatherings, written in ink at the foot of the last page of the gathering.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet, with rules in centre of head and side margins for aligning running heads and marginal headings (see diagram comparing Cirencester manuscripts in Gullick, 6). Pricking on all edges of the page for line spacing (6 mm) and frame.

handDesc.handNote: Gothic textualis, at least three scribes. Part written and corrected by Walter de Melida (see Gullick, 4–7), a canon active at Cirencester from c.1180 until after the death of Alexander Neckam in 1217.

decoDesc.decoNote: Large initials open the major sections of the work; those on fols. 1r, 2r, and 3r have been cut out, though remnants of gold leaf are visible, with initials probably in imitation of Barlow 6. Remaining on fol. 11r (begining of book 2) is an 11-line Arabeque initial in red and blue, with penwork in red, green, and yellow. Other books open with smaller initials: book 3, fol. 30r, a four-line initial in blue with red penwork; book 4, fol. 41v, an 8-line initial in red with blue penwork; book 5, fol. 50r, a 7-line initial in red with blue penwork and 8-line in blue with red penwork; book 6, a 4-line initial in red with blue penwork; book 7, fol. 82r, a 6-line initial in red with blue penwork; book 8, fol. 106v, a long I in the margin in blue with red and green penwork. New chapters generally open with a 2-line initial, altering somewhat inconsistently between red, green, yellow, and blue, sometimes with penwork in one or more of the other colours. Marginal labels rubricated and accompanied by a large paraph mark in red, blue, green, or yellow, occasionally with a decorative border.

binding.p: Gothic, whittawed leather over oak boards. Remnants of a red and yellow headband; blue and white stitching.
binding.condition: Sewing is deteriorated and loose due to removal of Proba gatherings. Repairs carried out in November 1983.

history.origin: Written at Cirencester Abbey. According to an inscription, the Malmesbury manuscript from which the book was copied was produced while Robert of Melun was abbot, between 1189/90 and 1205 (Oxford, Bodleian Library, Barlow 6, fol. 209r). It was likely produced between 1190 and 1210.
history.provenance: Lower flyleaf: Robert ap powell ap rychard ap lln’ = llewellyn of plwyth lantowny in comit. Herford (17th-century).
Owned by John Prise. See Neil R. Ker, ‘Sir John Prise’, The Library, 5th ser., 10, no. 1 (March 1955): 1–24 (at 16).
history.acquisition: Given to the Bodleian by Thomas Barlow.
